results.reasoning: Pineal region mass causing obstructive hydrocephalus, managed with ETV and biopsy during the procedure, non-resectable requiring radical radiotherapy with excellent response. Classic for germinoma (intracranial germ cell tumor), which is radiosensitive. Imaging shows midline posterior third ventricular/pineal mass with post-RT resolution of hydrocephalus. Age 43 plausible, though peak younger. Other options less fitting: meningioma surgically resectable, dermoid fatty not RT primary, tectal glioma low-grade no biopsy/RT, pineoblastoma pediatric.

Postoperative CT-urography shows fluid collection adjacent to ureters with extravasation of contrast (arrows in images 5-8), consistent with iatrogenic ureteral injury and urinoma during pelvic surgery. Preop images show anatomy for planning, but abnormality is postop urinary leak.

MRI shows a well-defined lobulated mass at volar wrist intimately related to tendon sheath, isointense on T1 (images 1-3), hypointense on T2 (images 4-6) with possible heterogeneous enhancement or cystic components, classic for giant cell tumor of tendon sheath, the most common solid soft tissue tumor in this location. Ganglion would be T2 hyperintense. Fibroma rarer, more uniform low signal. No rapid growth for nodular fasciitis.

Unilocular cystic mass in left abdomen with internal echoes/debris on US suggestive of complex fluid, thick enhancing wall and peri-lesional fat stranding on CT indicating inflammation/infection. Acute presentation with fever/leukocytosis favors complicated congenital cyst like enteric duplication cyst, common in mesentery/retroperitoneum, presenting in adults with infection. Lymphangioma multilocular; pseudocyst lacks trauma history; mesothelial/simple enteric typically asymptomatic/simple walls.

13-year-old girl with right adnexal mass on US, elevated androstenedione (androgen precursor). SLCT typically androgen-producing sex cord-stromal tumor in young females. MRI shows large heterogeneous solid-cystic mass consistent with SLCT. Pathology images confirm SCLT (Sertoli-Leydig) with retiform pattern and poorly differentiated areas.

Rectal GIST typically presents as a submucosal solid lesion on digital exam, causing bleeding. MRI shows well-circumscribed mass with heterogeneous T2 signal (hyperintense periphery, hypointense center if necrotic), restricted diffusion, and strong enhancement on post-contrast, matching the images: round mass on left rectal wall (T2 images 1-2), high signal on DWI (images 3-4 indicating restriction), and avid enhancement (image 5). Other options less likely: adenocarcinoma infiltrative/not well-defined submucosal; carcinoid smaller/homogeneous; lymphoma diffuse; haemangioma T2 very hyperintense with flow voids.

The patient presents with a growing mass in the ankle causing posterior tibial nerve compression symptoms. Imaging shows a soft tissue mass posterior to the distal tibia, likely in the location of the tarsal tunnel. The known osteochondroma is a bony lesion pointed on radiographs, but the growing symptomatic mass is separate soft tissue mass, consistent with a neurogenic tumor (e.g., schwannoma) arising along the posterior tibial nerve, explaining the specific nerve compression symptoms. Other options are less likely: sarcomas typically do not specifically cause isolated nerve compression symptoms, and imaging appears more fusiform/lobulated without aggressive bone destruction.

Patient with fever, flank pain, horseshoe kidney, urolithiasis. Imaging shows rim-enhancing cystic lesion in left kidney moiety on CT (peripheral enhancement in arterial and portal phases, hypodense on non-contrast), complex on US. Classic for renal abscess in setting of infection risk from stones/anomalous kidney.

Classic CT findings of epiploic appendagitis with central dot sign (thrombosed vessel) in an oval hyperdense fatty mass with surrounding stranding in the right lower quadrant (Images 3,4,5). US shows corresponding hypoechoic rimmed mass (Images 1,6). Specimen photograph (Image 2) matches resected infarcted epiploic appendage: small lobulated reddened fatty mass. Clinical presentation mimics appendicitis but mild CRP elevation without leukocytosis fits. Other options less likely: Meckel's would show bowel wall thickening, duplication cyst cystic, omental infarct larger/wedge-shaped.

Initial acquisition shows segmental narrowing in the sigmoid colon (arrows in images 2-3), suggesting possible stricture. Repeated acquisition demonstrates full distension without narrowing (images 4-7), indicating transient segmental colonic spasm artifact during water-enema CT colonography, resolving on repeat imaging. No signs of inflammation (A), mass (C,D), or persistent extrinsic effect (B).

7-year-old with rapidly enlarging abdominal mass, discomfort, weight loss. Imaging shows large heterogeneous retroperitoneal mass with solid and multiloculated cystic components, hypervascular on Doppler US. Typical for neuroblastoma, commonest abdominal malignancy in children, arising from adrenal/retroperitoneum, heterogeneous due to necrosis/hemorrhage. Other options less likely: liposarcoma rare in kids, no fat; desmoid solid no cysts; haemangioendothelioma rare site; NRSTS less common than neuroblastoma.

Chronic recurrent heel pain without sensory loss, MRI shows atrophy of abductor digiti minimi (ADM) muscle (Images 1-2: pathologic ADM labeled), sites of Baxter's nerve entrapment near calcaneal spur (Images 3-7), classic for chronic ICN/Baxter's neuropathy causing ADM atrophy, associated with plantar fasciitis. Not isolated PF (atrophy present), not lipoma/fibromatosis.

74yo male with obstructive jaundice, epigastric pain, fever, weight loss, anemia, high CA19-9. CT shows multiple hypodense liver lesions (mets) and masses/lymphadenopathy around pancreatic head/duodenum region causing biliary obstruction. Classic for pancreatic head carcinoma with liver metastases. CA19-9 highly suggestive of pancreatobiliary carcinoma. Not consistent with duodenitis (no masses/mets), lymphoma (CA19-9 atypical), Crohn's (no inflammation pattern, mets atypical). Metastatic disease descriptive but primary is carcinoma.

9-year-old with first seizure, temporal lobe lesion with multicystic 'bubbly' T2 hyperintense appearance, cortical based, minimal mass effect, classic for DNET which is strongly associated with seizures in children.

Posterior mediastinal mass seen on lateral chest X-ray (arrowed), confirmed on CT (axial, coronal, sagittal) as well-circumscribed, round, homogeneous mass in paravertebral region behind heart/anterior to spine. Asymptomatic adult patient. Neurogenic tumors are the most common posterior mediastinal masses, fitting imaging appearance perfectly. Others less likely: lymphoma typically anterior/multifocal; esophageal involves lumen; EMH lobulated/bilateral with hematologic disease; Castleman rarer and often intensely enhancing.

Unenhanced MRI demonstrates bilateral convoluted, tubular fluid-filled structures with thin walls in the adnexa, classic for hydrosalpinx. No fever, no thick enhancing walls or complex debris suggesting abscess. No solid nodules or ovarian masses for neoplasm. Consistent with sequelae of chronic PID. Urinary symptoms likely related to MS. Normal gyn exam 1 year ago suggests insidious process.

83yo male with cardiogenic shock and acute chest pain suggestive of MI complication. Hyperechoic pericardial effusion on echo indicates hemorrhagic effusion (hemopericardium). Most consistent with LV free wall rupture. VSR or papillary rupture wouldn't cause pericardial effusion. Aneurysm chronic. Dissection less likely without flap.

Sagittal T1 and post-contrast images show an irregular, heterogeneously enhancing pineal mass that invades the tectum and extends through the aqueduct causing obstructive hydrocephalus — illustrates aggressive, infiltrative behavior of pineoblastoma.

Non-contrast CT and post-contrast MR show a mildly hyperdense pineal mass with central calcification and avid, homogeneous enhancement — characteristic of germinoma and useful to distinguish from pineoblastoma which is usually heterogeneous and often lacks central calcification.

Serial MR images show a cystic pineal lesion with nodular/thickened enhancing wall and interval growth — a pattern that can mimic pineoblastoma (cystic/necrotic malignant lesion) and emphasizes the imaging features that raise suspicion for pineoblastoma vs benign pineal cyst.

CT and MR show a multiloculated heterogeneous pineal mass with areas of fat signal/low attenuation and calcification with fat droplets in subarachnoid spaces — classic for teratoma and helps exclude pineoblastoma which lacks macroscopic fat and typically shows homogeneous/heterogeneous solid enhancement and CSF dissemination.

results.reasoning: Early postoperative CT-urography demonstrates a pelvic fluid collection with internal high-attenuation material and extravasation of contrast from the right distal ureter (arrows in images 5-8), consistent with iatrogenic ureteral injury and urinoma during colonic recanalization surgery. Matches reference cases like 12226 showing opacification of collection on delayed phase from ureter leak. Distinguishes from abscess/seroma (no opacification or wall enhancement), enteric leak (no tracking from bowel), ascites (loculated).

relevant_cases_loaded.reason: Pelvic fluid collection is partially opacified on delayed/excretory-phase CT (higher attenuation within collection) with a visible track of contrast from the right distal ureter into the collection — classic CT-urography demonstration of iatrogenic ureteral leak/urinoma after pelvic surgery.

Perinephric/retroperitoneal fluid collection shows marked increased attenuation on excretory-phase CT consistent with extravasated opacified urine; 3D reformations show relationship to collecting system — demonstrates how delayed imaging identifies urinoma and differentiates it from abscess/seroma.

Medial perirenal extraluminal opacified urine originating at the ureteropelvic junction on excretory-phase CT with opacified proximal ureter — example of ureter/UPJ disruption causing urinoma and how delayed phase localizes injury level.

CT urography shows clear extravasation of iodinated contrast from both ureters into a large retroperitoneal fluid collection (urinoma) with progressive increase in attenuation on delayed images — demonstrates direct visualization of contrast leak and extent of urinoma.

Delayed excretory-phase CT shows opacification of the vagina (and tract) from the urinary bladder/ureteral system indicating a urinary fistula; useful to distinguish vesicovaginal or uretero-vaginal fistula versus urinoma and to localize source of urinary leak after pelvic surgery.

results.reasoning: MRI shows well-defined mass isointense to muscle on T1 (images 1-3), heterogeneously hyperintense on T2 (image 6), with peripheral enhancement (images 4-5). No evidence of susceptibility artifacts or low T2 signal indicative of hemosiderin, distinguishing from GCTTS/PVNS (refs 1066,18540,885,15087). Matches FTS features in ref 8890 (T1 isointense, T2 hyperintense, no GRE artifacts). Volar wrist location consistent with tenosynovial mass. Ganglion unlikely due to enhancement and not purely cystic. Others less matching.

relevant_cases_loaded.reason: MRI shows a well-defined tenosynovial mass isointense to muscle on T1 with no susceptibility artifacts on GRE (absence of hemosiderin) and collagenous hypocellular histology — imaging pattern supports fibroma of the tendon sheath (FTS)

GCTTS case with low-intermediate signal on T1 and T2 attributed to hemosiderin and strong post-contrast enhancement — demonstrates imaging features (hemosiderin-related low signal and marked enhancement) that help differentiate GCTTS from FTS

Localized tenosynovial giant cell tumour showing T1 hypointense mass, areas of signal drop on susceptibility/FFE (blooming from hemosiderin) and prominent enhancement — useful to exclude FTS when susceptibility artifacts are present

Diffuse tenosynovial giant cell tumour (PVNS) with T1/T2 low-signal hemosiderin, bone erosions and enhancing synovium on MRI — these features (blooming, erosions) contrast with FTS and aid differential diagnosis
GCTTS example with low signal intensity on T1 and T2 due to hemosiderin deposition evident on MR images — reinforces that presence of hemosiderin/susceptibility favors GCTTS over FTS
CT shows a large thin-walled multiloculated mesenteric cystic mass with thin enhancing septa and fluid attenuation (8-10 HU) matching the multiloculated appearance of lymphangioma.

CT demonstrates a large lobulated thin-walled multicystic mesenteric mass with contents varying from water to fat attenuation and intimate bowel relation — imaging evidence of chylous/fatty content and multiloculation typical of lymphangioma.

CT shows a multiloculated cystic mesenteric lesion with thin enhancing internal septa, lobulated borders, mass effect and complications (small-bowel obstruction, whirlpool sign) — illustrates how lymphangioma can present with inflammatory/complication-related changes and enhancing septa as in the target case.

CT and MRI demonstrate a cystic mesenteric lesion with central fat density/signal and circular wall enhancement plus surrounding mesenteric inflammatory changes — directly supports chylous (fat) content and infection/inflammation in lymphangioma.

Ultrasound and CT show an enteric duplication cyst with thick enhancing wall, ‘gut-signature’ (inner echogenic mucosa and outer muscular layer) and a shared wall with the duodenum — useful to distinguish duplication cyst from lymphangioma which lacks the gut wall signature.

CT shows a cystic omental teratoma with fat-fluid level and calcified/solid Rokitansky protuberance — demonstrates imaging features (calcification/solid elements) that favour teratoma over lymphangioma and help exclude this differential.

Pelvic MRI shows a well-circumscribed right adnexal mass with mixed solid and cystic architecture; solid component is intermediate on T1 and low–intermediate on T2 with scattered high-T2 areas — pattern and clinical androgen excess support androgen-producing Sertoli-Leydig cell tumour (matches target case imaging: solid/cystic, intermediate–high T2).

Large heterogeneous predominantly solid ovarian mass with central cystic area and prominent feeding vessels converging to the hilum; enhancing solid capsule and internal enhancement on post-contrast MRI/CT — demonstrates the hypervascular, solid–cystic appearance typical of sex-cord stromal tumours and helps confirm vascular solid phenotype seen in SLCT.

Well-defined solid ovoid ovarian mass with homogeneous low T1, central high T2 signal and a peripheral low-T2 rim with early avid peripheral enhancement — imaging pattern typical of sclerosing stromal tumour, useful to distinguish from SLCT by its characteristic peripheral low-T2 rim and early peripheral enhancement.

Adnexal lesion with very low T2 signal focus on MRI (and mild delayed enhancement on post-contrast imaging) consistent with fibrous tissue (fibroma/thecoma) — this low-T2 fibrous signature helps exclude fibrous stromal tumours in the differential for an SLCT, which usually shows intermediate–high T2 signal.

Heterogeneous solid adnexal mass with T1 and T2 signal similar to myometrium, internal cysts hyperintense on T2 and strong heterogeneous post-contrast enhancement — imaging of granulosa cell tumour that overlaps with SLCT features (solid/cystic, enhancing), highlighting the need for integration of imaging, age and hormonal findings to differentiate these entities.

Pelvic MRI: bulky ovoid, homogeneous rectal mass with well-defined margins, diffuse concentric wall thickening, homogeneous post-contrast enhancement and marked diffusion restriction — imaging pattern consistent with rectal B-cell lymphoma and supports lymphoma over adenocarcinoma or GIST.

CT/MRI: extensive concentric, homogeneous rectal wall thickening with smooth margins and minimal mesorectal invasion and diffusion restriction — pattern typical for rectal lymphoma (high cellularity) and helps distinguish from focal adenocarcinoma or GIST which are usually more heterogeneous and infiltrative.

Rectal MRI: 3 cm submucosal lesion with low T2 signal, no gadolinium enhancement and low signal on high-b DWI — imaging typical of endometriosis (non-enhancing, T2-dark) and useful to exclude lymphoma which shows T2 hyperintensity, enhancement and diffusion restriction.

MR and EUS: polypoid anorectal lesion with intrinsic high T1 signal (melanin), low T2 signal and diffusion restriction — imaging features characteristic of anorectal melanoma and help differentiate it from lymphoma (which does not show intrinsic T1 hyperintensity).

Contrast-enhanced CT of gastric MALT lymphoma: diffuse homogeneous wall thickening with preserved fat planes and marked shrinkage after chemotherapy — demonstrates typical homogeneous involvement and chemo-responsiveness of MALT lymphoma, a pattern analogous to extranodal GI MALT including rectum.

results.reasoning: CT images demonstrate multiple small round hypodense lesions ('bubbles') in subcutaneous tissues of mammary region, gluteal region, and thighs bilaterally, classic for self-injected oil or liquid silicone/fillers. Matches reference cases 17026, 16557 showing similar subcutaneous nodules from injections. Clinical abdominal symptoms likely unrelated/incidental colon finding. Other options mismatch imaging: mets solid, neurofibromas soft tissue density, fat nodules not bubbly, air unlikely.

relevant_cases_loaded.reason: CT shows multiple bilateral isodense subcutaneous nodulations with surrounding fat stranding in the buttocks and US demonstrates the ‘snowstorm’ increased noise appearance consistent with free injected silicone/liquid filler — imaging pattern similar to subcutaneous oil bubbles.

Neck US shows ‘cloudy’ high echogenicity with marked posterior enhancement (snowstorm sign) in supraclavicular node and silicone-specific MRI demonstrates high signal within the node; FDG-PET/CT shows metabolically active node — illustrates migration of injected silicone to nodes and imaging features that can mimic metastases, helping differentiate injected oil/silicone from true nodal metastasis.

Mammography demonstrates multiple scattered linear and round high-density opacities in the breast and US shows extremely echogenic masses with dirty shadowing (snowstorm sign) — classic imaging of direct self-injection of silicone/fillers resembling subcutaneous oil nodules seen on CT/US.

FDG-PET/CT reveals intensely FDG-avid calcifications within subcutaneous tissues at filler injection sites — demonstrates that injected fillers can be FDG-avid and mimic skin/soft-tissue metastases on PET/CT, an important differential when evaluating multiple subcutaneous nodules.

Breast US and mammography of an oil cyst (post-traumatic fat necrosis) show a fat-containing oval mass with thin capsule, peripheral echogenic mural nodules and posterior acoustic enhancement — provides the classic ‘oil cyst’ appearance and helps distinguish organized oil-containing cysts from scattered free oil droplets or metastases.

US shows lobulated hypoechoic soft-tissue mass with marked hypervascularity on power Doppler; MRI T1 hypointense/T2 hyperintense lesion with diffusion restriction and heterogeneous centripetal contrast enhancement (necrotic areas) and PET-CT hypermetabolism — imaging pattern strongly supports malignant small-round-cell tumour (extraskeletal Ewing sarcoma) rather than benign neurogenic lesion.

Contrast CT shows an extrapulmonary paravertebral heterogeneously enhancing soft-tissue mass with no vertebral bone invasion — demonstrates extraskeletal presentation of Ewing sarcoma in soft tissues and differentiates from primary bone Ewing or benign nerve sheath tumours that typically show nerve-related morphology.

Abdominal CT shows a solid, non-homogeneous mass with hypodense/necrotic areas and multiple peritoneal/omental implants and nodal disease — pattern of aggressive soft-tissue tumour dissemination consistent with extraskeletal Ewing sarcoma and helps exclude localized benign/vascular lesions.

Thoracic CT demonstrates a large anterior mediastinal heterogeneously enhancing mass with cystic/hemorrhagic areas and heterogeneous enhancement — indicates aggressive soft-tissue sarcoma (extraskeletal Ewing) in an atypical location and helps distinguish from homogenous lymphoproliferative or purely cystic germ cell lesions.

Perirenal capillary haemangioma: CT and MRI show a well-circumscribed nodule with peripheral hyperenhancement that persists into the portal phase and a T2-hyperintense centre (target-like appearance) with a feeding vessel — imaging pattern matches the peripheral/persistent enhancement seen in renal haemangioma (and similar to case 11532) and supports a diagnosis of vascular/Blood-filled lesion.

Renal anastomosing haemangioma: small (1 cm) intrarenal nodule that is isodense to the blood pool across arterial and parenchymal phases with vivid homogeneous arterial enhancement — demonstrates that renal haemangiomas can be intensely hypervascular and may mimic RCC; recognition of isodensity to blood pool and early enhancement helps identify a vascular haemangioma variant.

Giant cavernous hepatic haemangioma: classic peripheral globular/nodular enhancement with progressive centripetal fill-in on multiphase CT and eventual uniform enhancement — exemplar of the canonical haemangioma enhancement pattern (peripheral nodular enhancement with centripetal fill-in) that supports interpreting peripheral nodular/persistent enhancement in renal lesions as haemangioma rather than cystic neoplasm or abscess.

Solitary fibrous tumour of the renal sinus (contrast): lobulated, solid renal sinus mass with relatively homogeneous attenuation and no peripheral nodular enhancement or persistent peripheral rim — useful as a negative comparator to distinguish haemangioma (which shows peripheral nodular/persistent or target-like enhancement and high T2 signal) from other renal-sinus tumours that enhance homogeneously.

CT shows a thick-walled blind-ending tubular structure arising from the distal ileum separate from a normal appendix, with surrounding fat stranding and mesenteric lymphadenopathy — classic imaging for Meckel's diverticulitis and distinguishes it from appendicitis.

Contrast-enhanced CT demonstrates a localized fluid collection adjacent to thickened small bowel and reactive mesenteric changes consistent with an inflamed Meckel's diverticulum (surgically confirmed). The focal collection and adjacent bowel wall thickening support the diagnosis.

CT shows a fluid-filled distended structure at the distal ileum with an avidly enhancing intraluminal nodule (gastric heterotopia) and transition point; operative findings of torsion/strangulation confirm Meckel's — illustrates presentation with obstruction and heterotopic mucosa.

Ultrasound demonstrates a mass connected to small bowel with alternating echotexture, hyperechoic mesenteric fat and prominent mesenteric nodes, which at surgery proved to be a perforated Meckel's diverticulum — shows sonographic features that can mimic intussusception but are pathognomonic when a neck to small bowel is seen.

CT shows a rounded fluid collection with air-fluid level and faecal material near the ileum with minimal fat stranding; differential included ruptured appendix vs Meckel's, with surgery confirming strangulated Meckel's diverticulitis — demonstrates how Meckel can mimic appendiceal abscess on CT.

Large lumbosacral intradural extramedullary mass isointense on T1, hyperintense on T2, with intense post-contrast enhancement and T2* hypointense foci (intratumoral haemorrhage) plus vertebral scalloping and craniospinal dissemination — imaging features of myxopapillary ependymoma that support the diagnosis in the target case.

Well-defined tubular/sausage-shaped long-segment intradural extramedullary lesion within thecal sac that is T2 hyperintense and shows intense homogeneous enhancement, compressing cauda equina — matches the sausage-shaped enhancing L2-L3 lesion in the target and supports ependymoma.

Lumbosacral T2-hyperintense, heterogeneously enhancing mass with sacral extension and posterior vertebral scalloping/foraminal expansion — demonstrates aggressive lumbosacral ependymoma imaging pattern useful for confirming ependymoma and contrasting features (scalloping) absent in target.

Intraforaminal cystic lesion with neural foraminal widening and peripheral/ring-like enhancement consistent with schwannoma — provides imaging features that help differentiate nerve-sheath tumour from central intradural ependymoma in the differential diagnosis.

results.reasoning: Initial WE-CTC shows segmental non-distension/narrowing (arrows in images 2-3) mimicking pathology, resolving completely on repeated acquisition (images 4-7) after further distension/hypotonization. Matches transient spasm artefact (ref 15169). True pathology (carcinoma ref12572, IBD ref10189/2757, NSAID ref16556) persists. No mural thickening/enhancement/stranding excludes A-D. Benign history.

relevant_cases_loaded.reason: Arterial-phase CT shows a curved tubular air-density structure that disappears on portal-phase imaging — example of a transient intraluminal imaging artefact that resolves on repeat acquisition, analogous to the colonic segmental spasm in the target case which vanished after further distension and hypotonisation.

Water-enema CT colonography demonstrates a fixed 6-cm stricturing sigmoid carcinoma with circumferential enhancing mural thickening, abrupt shouldering proximally and distally, and persistent upstream faecal loading — shows the imaging pattern of true malignancy that can mimic spasm but does NOT resolve on repeat acquisition, helping to differentiate carcinoma from transient spasm.

WE‑MDCT shows a rigid, poorly distended descending colon with moderate circumferential enhancing wall thickening, pseudopolyps and pericolonic fat hyperaemia (comb sign) — an inflammatory/fibrotic pattern causing persistent poor distension that helps distinguish chronic disease from transient segmental spasm artifact.

CT colonography cases show smooth, plate-like pin‑hole strictures and focal luminal narrowings (NSAID diaphragm disease) that are unchanged on interval imaging/endoluminal reconstructions — an example of fixed strictures that can mimic focal non‑distension but are persistent, unlike transient spasm.

CTC virtual endoscopy demonstrates multiple broad-based polypoid-appearing lesions that correspond to gas‑filled intramural cysts (pneumatosis coli) — an intraluminal mimic on CTC distinguished by intramural gas and lack of mural enhancement or shouldering, unlike spasm artifact.

Barium enema shows a long narrow, stiff tubular colon with a ‘string sign’ from muscular spasm and fibrosis in ulcerative colitis — illustrates how muscular spasm (chronic/fibrotic) can produce severe luminal narrowing, but the chronic rigid appearance and flattened haustra help distinguish it from the transient, reversible segmental colonic spasm seen in the target case.

Large heterogeneous retroperitoneal soft-tissue mass on CT with abundant intratumoural tortuous vessels and progressive enhancement; compresses but does not invade adjacent organs — imaging pattern consistent with NRSTS (malignant fibrous histiocytoma) and supports diagnosis of retroperitoneal NRSTS.

Large retroperitoneal mass on CT with heterogeneous soft-tissue attenuation but with macroscopic fatty areas (fatty attenuation) and septations — imaging appearance diagnostic of dedifferentiated liposarcoma, an important differential to exclude when considering NRSTS (presence of macroscopic fat helps distinguish liposarcoma from NRSTS).

Pediatric adrenal-origin masses on US/MRI with vessel encasement and metastatic liver nodules; classic features for neuroblastoma including adrenal location and vascular encasement — imaging features that help differentiate neuroblastoma from NRSTS in children.

Well-defined, rounded-oval fluid-attenuating mass on CT occupying the greater omentum/mesentery with thin septations and lack of aggressive vascular encasement — imaging features compatible with mesenteric desmoid/benign cystic lesion, which helps distinguish noninfiltrative cystic masses from aggressive heterogeneous NRSTS.

Shoulder MRI shows focal suprascapular nerve enlargement and T2 hyperintensity at the suprascapular notch with acute muscle oedema and chronic fatty atrophy of supraspinatus/infraspinatus — demonstrates the MRI pattern of denervation (acute STIR/T2 hyperintensity followed by chronic T1 fatty replacement) analogous to selective abductor digiti minimi fatty replacement in Baxter neuropathy.

Pelvic MRI demonstrates obturator nerve thickening and T2 hyperintensity where the nerve is encased by iliac adenopathy, with oedema in obturator-innervated muscles and secondary mild fatty atrophy — an example of peripheral nerve entrapment producing selective muscle denervation and fatty replacement, matching the mechanism in Baxter neuropathy.

MR shows increased T2/STIR signal (muscle oedema) and T1 hyperintense fatty infiltration/atrophy of muscles supplied by the anterior interosseous nerve — a clear example of focal motor denervation causing selective fatty muscle replacement, supporting interpretation of abductor digiti minimi fatty change as neurogenic.

High-resolution US and MR demonstrate a well-defined, encapsulated lipomatous mass enveloping the tibialis anterior tendon with homogeneous high T1 signal, internal septations and complete fat suppression on PD-FS — imaging features that distinguish an encapsulated lipoma from diffuse neurogenic fatty muscle replacement and help exclude intramuscular lipoma as a cause of abductor digiti minimi change.

Lacks thick walls, enhancement, debris, gas seen in abscess/TOA (refs 15389,10362). No peritoneal thickening/ascites/pulmonary findings for TB (ref 11883). Not ovarian mass. Stable on follow-up US.

relevant_cases_loaded.reason: TVUS and contrast-enhanced CT show tubular multiloculated adnexal collections with fluid/fluid layering, thick hypervascular septa and thick-enhancing walls — imaging classic for pyosalpinx/tubo-ovarian complex (TOA).

Transvaginal US and contrast-enhanced CT demonstrate an 8-cm multiloculated adnexal complex mass with thickened peripheral wall and contrast-enhancing septa — features typical of tubo-ovarian abscess; adjacency to inflamed sigmoid colon shows secondary TOA from diverticulitis.

Contrast-enhanced CT shows a parauterine fluid collection with internal air and surrounding fat stranding adjacent to sigmoid diverticulitis — presence of internal gas within adnexal collection and inflammatory change strongly supports abscess (tubo-ovarian abscess) rather than neoplasm.

Contrast-enhanced CT shows a fluid-containing tubular adnexal structure with enhancing walls, associated peritoneal enhancement/ascites and an IUD — imaging pattern consistent with pyosalpinx/tubo-ovarian abscess and severe PID.

Multicystic adnexal masses with thick contrast-enhancing walls and marked peritoneal thickening/ascites on CT/MRI can mimic TOA; associated pulmonary nodules and necrotic mediastinal nodes and preserved normal ovaries in this case indicate pelvic tuberculosis — useful differential-imaging features to distinguish TB from TOA.

Contrast-enhanced CT angiography shows a lobulated saccular pseudoaneurysm disrupting the basal anterior interventricular septum with a visible defect and direct communication between the LV cavity and the RV — demonstrates how post‑MI septal rupture/pseudoaneurysm appears as a contrast‑filled septal defect connecting ventricles.

ECG-gated CT shows a clearly visualized subaortic ventricular septal defect (~2.7 cm) on coronal/sagittal reformats — provides anatomic example of an intracardiac septal defect and its location for comparison with post‑infarction septal rupture morphology.

Pulmonary‑arterial phase CT demonstrates isolated early enhancement of the left ventricular outflow tract consistent with contrast passage through a reopened VSD (right‑to‑left shunt) — shows the contrast timing/early enhancement sign used to detect intracardiac shunts after infarction.

Emergency MDCT shows high‑attenuation haemopericardium and contrast extravasation through a full‑thickness discontinuity of the LV free wall into the pericardial sac — exemplary imaging of free‑wall rupture and haemopericardium to differentiate from interventricular septal rupture, which produces intracardiac communication rather than pericardial extravasation.

Non‑ECG gated CT after penetrating trauma demonstrates dense heterogeneous pericardial effusion (~50 HU) and linear high‑density contrast tracking into the pericardial sac anterior to the RV apex consistent with myocardial perforation and active extravasation — a trauma example of free‑wall rupture/perforation to contrast with septal rupture imaging features.
